title: ci: remove pkg update on cirrus
client: proper cleanup on send on system impl
body:
This ensures that the user_data associated with a proxy is
correctly cleaned up when sending a destructor request.

Also, the dispatch logic was updated to correctly handle the case where
an object is destroyed from within its own dispatch closure.

Fixes #358

title: simple window xdg
body:
This updates the simple window example to use xdg protocol.

Tested on Fedora 33 and TinyWL.

Resolves https://github.com/Smithay/wayland-rs/issues/315

title: Make crates buildable with minimal dependency versions
body:
Some dependencies seems outdated, and does not compile with rustc 1.49.0.
This pull request bumps some dependencies in order to all crates compile with minimal dependency versions.

You can generate `Cargo.lock` with minimal dependency versions by `cargo +nightly update -Z minimal-versions`.
(Once `Cargo.lock` is generated, build and test can be proceeded by stable rustc.)

This PR chose literally minimum compilable deps versions to minimize unexpected side effects, but it results in compiler warnings in some crates (for example, `lazy-static v1.0.2` uses `std::sync::ONCE_INIT` internally, [which is now deprecated](https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/std/sync/constant.ONCE_INIT.html)).
I think some dependencies should be updated to more recent versions, but it is out of scope of this PR.

title: Unset WAYLAND_SOCKET when we use the socket
body:
Since we are either taking ownership of the socket or closing it at this point,
we should not retain the environment variable as it will only confuse child
processes.

title: wayland-commons: avoid empty sendmsg on flush
body:
If there is nothing to send, there's no point actually making the system call.
The list of FDs is not checked because sending FDs without also sending data is
not permitted anyway.

title: client: early return parsing when encountering a protocol error
body: Overwise the event is queued like any other, the  next read triggers a broken pipe, and only that last error is reported to the user.

title: cursor: account for both width and height when picking nearest cursor
body:
Cursors don't have square form in general, so we should match
both width and height when picking nearest images.

title: Update wlr-protocols
body: foreign-toplevel-management version 3 introduces a new message.

title: cursor: fix crash when memfd isn't available
Update core protocol to 1.18
body: Fixes #348.

title: Update dependencies
body: This commit bumps nix to 0.18 and parking_lot to 0.11

title: client: Summon dead Proxies for dead arguments
body:
When we receive an event with a non-nullable object argument which
points to a non-existing object, summon a dead object to replace it
rather than crashing.

This can happen if we destroyed the target object conccurently with the
server sending us this event, and we should not crash due to that.

Fixes #334

title: modernize simple_window example
body:
This follows #336 further modernizing the `simple_window` example. 

* remove `extern crate`
* remove `macro_use`
* nested `use` statements
* replace unwraps with `?` by returning `Result` from `main`
* correct or allow all clippy lints

Let me know if there is anything you don't like in here. I also tried to update/extend the comments, but my wayland knowledge is minimal so there wasn't much I could do there. I'd be happy to do this for the remaining examples if there is interest in that.

title: remove byteorder dependency for wayland-client example
body: As of Rust 1.32, there is a method in the standard library to convert a u32 to a native endian byte slice. This PR takes advantage of this method to remove the dependency on the `byteorder` crate for the `simple-window` example.

title: scanner: parse event type from xml
body:
See https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/wayland/wayland/-/merge_requests/82.

Once protocol files are updated, this will remove the need for workarounds to specify these separately.

title: client: server: scanner: Make crate more debuggable
body:
Implement std::fmt::Debug on various server and client core wrappers and
and so make Event/Request to derive std::fmt::Debug impl.

Fixes #311.

title: Remove dependency on xcur
body:
The `xcur` crate had some bugs, so here is a new implementation which (hopefully) fixes them.
@vberger

title: client: Don't lock the queue buffer too long
body:
In dispatch_pending(), don't keep the buffer locked for the whole
dispatching, but instead lock it in a per-message basis. Otherwise,
we may conflict with the locks required by read_messages() if called
concurently.

read_messages() locking needs are:

```
-> lock connection
  -> lock map
    -> punctual locks of queue buffers
```

dispatch_pending() locking strategy was, before this commit:

```
-> lock buffer
  -> punctual locks of map
```

This commit changes it to:

```
-> punctual locks of buffer
-> punctual locks if map
```

This means a dispatch_pending() can now be interrupted by a read_event
from an other thread. It'll just resume its dispatching once the read
is finished.

title: cursor: don't panic if load_cursor fails
[WIP] Make the `cursor` feature full rust
body:
~~This PR inserts a Rust implementation into the wayland-cursor crate, but allowing to fallback to the system wayland-cursor.so, for interoperability with other libraries.
The rust implementation is backwards compatible for the most part (except for some lifetimes that aren't needed anymore).~~

This PR reimplements in Rust the `wayland-cursor` crate. The API is changed to be hopefully more Rust-y, since we don't have the c library to follow anymore.

title: client: track display lifetime in proxies
body:
When attempting to send a message from a proxy and using the `use_system_lib`, check if the associated `Display` is actually still alive before calling into FFI. If not, behave as a dead proxy.

This should fix a number of crashes associated to destructors and final cleanups in apps, when a component than sends wayland requests from its destructor happened to be dropped after the display.

title: Resolve clippy warnings
body:
* Abolish deprecated method `description` of `::std::error::Error.`
 * Factorize complex type into `type` definitions in `wayland-protocols/build.rs`

title: fix typo in README.md
body: I fixed it that seems a typo in README.md.

title: client/server: introduce DispatchData
body:
The DispatchData mechanism allows global data to be shared by the scope
calling dispatch() with all callbacks that dispatch() invokes, at the
cost of some small runtime checks (basically Any::downcast).

body: Doesn't appear to actually make a difference but for the sake of correctness

title: commons: use smallvec to store message arguments
body:
Any message with 4 argument or less will have these arguments stored
inline rather than in an heap-allocated vec.

The number 4 was chose because almost all messages have 4 arguments
or less, and some potentially very spammy messages (wl_touch.move)
have exactly 4 arguments. Avoiding allocations in these cases should
generally be a gain.

Moreother, to avoid bloating the size of Message due to this,
String and Array arguments are further boxed, reducing the size
of Argument from 4 usize to 2 usize. These kind of arguments are
generally pretty rare, so the double allocation should overall not
counter the size gain.

Also contains a commit finishing some 2018-ification work.

Closes #268
Closes #249

title: Filter api
body:
Rework of the API of the wayland crates.

Notable changes:

- no more `implement_*` method, instead objects are assigned to `Filter`s, which are some kind of shareable callback. meaning that more than one object can be assigned to a given callback.
- Rather than the dance with `Newproxy`/`NewResource`, proxies and ressources can be assigned and re-assigned to filters. If a message is received for an object not assigned to any filter the result depends on the side:
  - client-side, the message is given to a generic callback that the user has to provide to the `dispatch` methods. The client can thus decide to handle some messages manually rather than via the callbacks.
  - server-side, a message is printed to stderr, and the client is killed with a protocol error message indicating of a server bug.
- client-side, the multithreading handling is done using the new `Main<I>` and `Attached<I>` type (in addition of the `Proxy<I>`/`I` already existing):
  - `Main<I>` is the initial created handle, it is not `Send`, and can be used to send any request and change the proxy assignation to a filter. It cannot exist on an other thread than the one hosting the event queue managing the proxy.
  - `Proxy<I>` is the most shareable handle. It is `Send`, but can only be used to send requests that do *not* create new objects.
  - `Attached<I>` can be created from a `Proxy<I>` by "attaching" the handle to an event queue. It can be used to send any requests, and requests creating new objects will have these new objects managed by the event queue the handle is "attached" to. It is not `Send`.
- Server-side, there is a `Main<I>` as well. Event dispatching & assigning filters can only be done from the thread hosting the `Display`, which is still not threadsafe.
- Client-side: creating a new connection does no longer automatically create a new event queue. You need to create you own, and attach a handle of the `WlDisplay` to it to get your `WlRegistry`.
- User-data is now represented as a `UserData` type, with `set`/`get` methods. It can only be set once and handles thread-safety correctly.
- the `native_lib` feature is renamed to `use_system_lib`, to be more explicit
- client-side: `wayland-cursor` and `wayland-egl` are split into their own crates

TODO:

- [x] polish & uniformize the API
- [x] Update the documentation
- [x] Erase any trace of the event loop abstraction to fully decouple the crate from calloop
